comment.author: 71519166@N08
comment._content: Cdr Cedric Naylor born 12 June 1891, DSO and 2 Bars,DSC. Served in RNR, transferred to RN with seniority as Lieutenant 19 December 1916 and Lieutenant Commander 19 December 1924. retired as Commander 12 June 1936. Recalled for war service in 1939. Retired with War Service rank of Acting Captain in August 1945. Service record available online. www.nationalarchives.gov.uk/documentsonline/download.asp?...

comment.author: 8498561@N08
comment._content: Attended Preston Grammar School. Served on 'Q' Ships on anti submarine operations. An excellent write up of Cedric's very interesting war can be found at Preston Grammar School Article and HMS Penshurst Forum discussion on Lt Naylor Additional pictures DSC gazetted 16/02/1917. DSO gazetted 28/08/1917 "For services in action with enemy submarines". Confirmed Lieutenant (from Temporary Lieutenant) 27/09/1917 for distinguished service in action, with seniority from 19/12/1916. Bar to DSO gazetted 02/12/1917 "For services in action with enemy submarines". 2nd Bar to DSO gazetted 19/02/1918 "For services in action with enemy submarines". 1939 Master of the Fulham Road Institute

comment.author: 62508825@N00
comment._content: Source: Preston Grammar School article (above AndyBailey) In 1892 his father William Naylor, a civil engineer, lived at 45 Watling Street Road, Fulwood, Preston. When Cedric entered Preston Grammar School in September 1900, the family lived at 3 West View, Fulwood, Preston. His two younger brothers had enlisted on the outbreak of hostilities and (February 1917) were serving in the Royal Engineers in Egypt. Source: www.ww1.pgsassociation.org.uk/html/additional_list_one.html The father, William, was born about 1869 and his mother, Prisalla M, was born about 1866, both born in Crewe. Cedric was born in Wolverhampton, and his siblings were born in Preston. Ida was one year and Wilson was four years younger than Cedric; Briadley was a year younger than Wilson and Ruth was two years younger than Briadley. (In 1901 Census - 9, 8, 5, 4, 2 respectively.) Presumably Wilson and Briadley were the two younger brothers who enlisted in the Royal Engineers. It is not known if this was the complete family or if there were children after Ruth. In the household at 3 West View were a cook/domestic, Annie Franklin from Wexford; and a 15-year old housemaid, Emily Eastham, born in Preston. Source: Preston Grammar School article (above AndyBailey) Found dead in bed on Wednesday morning, a retired Naval captain, Mr Cedric Naylor, of “Redholme”, London Road. Died of a coronary thrombosis in Deal, Kent, on January 12, 1949 age 57. Buried at sea

comment.author: 62508825@N00
comment._content:
Info, especially misspellings are corrected through consulting freeBMD.co.uk
Naylor William  marriage registered 1st qr 1891 Nantwich 8a  566 to Priscilla Mary Bayley
Naylor Cedric    birth registered 3rd qr 1891  Wolverhampton 6b  542
Naylor Ida           birth registered 4th qr 1892  Preston 8e  649
Naylor Wilson    birth registered 4th qr 1895  Preston 8e  628
Naylor Brindley  birth registered 1st qr 1897  Preston 8e  687
Naylor Ruth        birth registered 2nd qr 1899 Preston 8e  666
Interestingly,  there is a Brindley Naylor birth reg 2nd qr 1894 and death reg  2nd qr 1896 in Preston
Names of brothers who joined the Royal Engineers are Wilson and Brindley.
Their British Army WWI Service Records can be found on ancestry.co.uk
Naylor Brindley marriage registered Metcalfe 2nd qr 1923 Chorlton 8c  1892
Naylor Brindley death registered 3rd qr 1959 N E Cheshire 10a  38
